author: R Krishna Kumar
text:
The Bandipur fire, which was suspected to be the handiwork of a few people visiting a local temple at Tavarekatte on Tuesday, brings the focus back on places of worship in tiger reserves, and the possible relocation of temples.

There are about six to eight such places of worship in Bandipur, besides 40 in Nagarahole. These are frequented by people from villages on the forest fringes. Though not all temples attract a huge crowd — people visit them only on a specific day in a year — there are a few that see frequent visitors.

Wildlife activists espousing temple relocation say festivals have been scaled up in recent years to include stage programmes and mass feeding, which entail the entry of a large number of vehicles and non-stop operation of diesel generator sets. These create noise and air pollution, disturbing wildlife. However, B.R. Praveen of Vanya — Let the Wild be Wild, an NGO advocating conservation, said a via media approach was ideal as relocation of temples at one go may not be practical. “While the rituals by priests can be held at the temples, the carnival associated with them should be encouraged to take place in the local villages,” he said.

Naveen Kumar, Honorary Wildlife Warden, Chamarajanagar, said temple relocation should be a slow and long-drawn process. “But if there is total restriction, it could lead to a backlash,” he said.

Other activists said temple relocation should be encouraged wherever possible. They said that leftover food and carcass of animals sacrificed tend to attract wild animals that get habituated to cooked food.
title: ‘Temple festivals pollute Bandipur tiger reserve’
